content.text: Bash scp Command - Secure Copy
Using the scp Command
The scp command is used to securely copy files between hosts on a network.
content.html: The scp command is used to securely copy files between hosts on a network.

content.text: Basic Usage
To copy a file to a remote host, use scp file user@hostname:/path :
content.html: To copy a file to a remote host, use scp file user@hostname:/path:

content.code:
scp
file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password:
file.txt
content.code_html:
scp file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password: 
file.txt

content.text: Options
The scp command supports various options to customize its behavior:
content.html: The scp command supports various options to customize its behavior:

content.text: Option: -r (Recursive Copy)
The -r option allows you to recursively copy entire directories.
content.html: The -r option allows you to recursively copy entire directories.

content.code_html:
scp -r /path/to/directory user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password: 
1.png 100% 1797KB   2.7MB/s   00:00    
2.png 100% 1873KB   3.2MB/s   00:00    
3.png 100% 1808KB   3.9MB/s   00:00    
...

content.text: Option: -P (Port)
The -P option allows you to specify a port to connect to on the remote host.
content.html: The -P option allows you to specify a port to connect to on the remote host.

content.text: By default, SCP uses port 22.

content.code:
scp
-P
2222
file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password:
file.txt
content.code_html:
scp -P 2222 file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password: 
file.txt

content.text: Option: -i (Identity File)
The -i option allows you to specify a private key file for authentication.
content.html: The -i option allows you to specify a private key file for authentication.

content.text: This is useful when you have a specific key for a server.
content.html: This is useful when you have a specific key for a server.

content.code_html:
scp -i /path/to/private_key file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
file.txt

content.text: Option: -C (Compression)
The -C option enables compression, which can speed up file transfer by reducing the amount of data sent over the network.
content.html: The -C option enables compression, which can speed up file transfer by reducing the amount of data sent over the network.

content.code:
scp
-C file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password:
file.txt
content.code_html:
scp -C file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password: 
file.txt

content.text: Option: -v (Verbose Mode)
The -v option enables verbose mode, providing detailed output about the file transfer process.
content.html: The -v option enables verbose mode, providing detailed output about the file transfer process.

content.text: This is helpful for debugging.

content.code:
scp
-v file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
Executing: program /usr/bin/ssh host example.com, user user, command scp -v -t /home/user/
file.txt 100% 1234KB 1.2MB/s 00:01
...
content.code_html:
scp -v file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
Executing: program /usr/bin/ssh host example.com, user user, command scp -v -t /home/user/
file.txt 100% 1234KB 1.2MB/s 00:01
...

content.text: Option: -l (Limit Bandwidth)
The -l option allows you to limit the bandwidth used by the copy. This is useful for managing network resources.
content.html: The -l option allows you to limit the bandwidth used by the copy. This is useful for managing network resources.

content.code:
scp
-l
100
file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password:
file.txt
content.code_html:
scp -l 100 file.txt user@example.com:/home/user/
user@example.com's password: 
file.txt
